Description: Small, red, raised bump without pus, typically inflamed
Common Causes: Excess sebum, dead skin cells clogging pores, bacterial infection (C. acnes), hormonal fluctuations
Initial Treatment: Topical retinoids (tretinoin), benzoyl peroxide, topical antibiotics (clindamycin)
Skincare Recommendations: Gentle cleansers, non-comedogenic moisturizers, oil-free sunscreen
Skincare Ingredients to Avoid: Heavy oils (coconut oil), alcohol-based toners, abrasive scrubs
When to Consult Dermatologist: No improvement after 6-8 weeks, severe inflammation, scarring
Combination Considerations: Combine with salicylic acid for blackheads, avoid over-drying
Skin Type Adjustments: Oily skin: light gel moisturizers, dry skin: hydrating non-comedogenic creams
Age-Specific Considerations: Teens: focus on oil control, adults: consider anti-aging ingredients like niacinamide

Description: Red, inflamed bump with visible white or yellow pus-filled center
Common Causes: Bacterial proliferation, excess oil, inflammatory response to clogged pores
Initial Treatment: Benzoyl peroxide, topical antibiotics (erythromycin), azelaic acid
OTC Ingredients: Benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, tea tree oil
Skincare Recommendations: Oil-free cleansers, non-comedogenic serums, clay masks
Skincare Ingredients to Avoid: Comedogenic makeup, thick creams, fragranced products
When to Consult Dermatologist: Persistent pustules, fever, or spreading redness
Combination Considerations: Use with non-drying retinoids to prevent irritation
Skin Type Adjustments: Sensitive skin: fragrance-free formulas, oily skin: mattifying products
Age-Specific Considerations: Adults: check for hormonal triggers, teens: avoid excessive scrubbing

Description: Large, painful, deep pus-filled lesion under the skin, often leading to scarring
Common Causes: Hormonal imbalances, genetic predisposition, severe inflammation
Initial Treatment: Oral antibiotics (doxycycline), intralesional steroid injections, isotretinoin
OTC Ingredients: Limited OTC options (warm compresses, hydrocolloid patches)
When to Consult Dermatologist: Severe pain, recurring cysts, scarring concerns
Combination Considerations: Avoid combining with abrasive treatments, prioritize anti-inflammatory care
Skin Type Adjustments: Dry skin: focus on barrier repair, oily skin: use lightweight hydration
Age-Specific Considerations: Adults: assess hormonal health, teens: monitor for severe outbreaks

Description: Hard, painful, deep lump beneath the skin surface without visible pus
Common Causes: Severe inflammation, hormonal fluctuations, genetic factors
Initial Treatment: Oral isotretinoin, corticosteroids, hormonal therapy (for women)
Skincare Recommendations: Soothing ingredients (centella asiatica), fragrance-free repair creams
When to Consult Dermatologist: Lesions persist beyond 6 weeks, significant discomfort
Combination Considerations: Combine with gentle acne treatments to avoid worsening inflammation
Skin Type Adjustments: Sensitive skin: avoid fragrances, normal skin: incorporate mild exfoliation
Age-Specific Considerations: Teens: caution with isotretinoin, adults: evaluate hormonal therapies

Description: Open comedone with darkened oxidized sebum plug, non-inflamed
Common Causes: Accumulated sebum and dead skin cells in open pores, oxidative stress
Skincare Recommendations: Exfoliating toners, oil-free primers, clay masks
Skincare Ingredients to Avoid: Thick occlusive oils (mineral oil), silicone-heavy products
When to Consult Dermatologist: Blackheads lead to inflamed acne or scarring
Combination Considerations: Pair with benzoyl peroxide for inflammatory acne prevention
Skin Type Adjustments: Oily skin: daily exfoliation, dry skin: limit exfoliation to 2-3x/week
Age-Specific Considerations: Teens: emphasize consistent cleansing, adults: address pore congestion

Description: Closed comedone with small, flesh-colored or white bump under skin
Common Causes: Trapped sebum and keratin in closed pores, mild inflammation
When to Consult Dermatologist: Whiteheads progress to inflamed acne, no improvement with OTC
Combination Considerations: Avoid combining multiple exfoliants to prevent barrier damage
Skin Type Adjustments: Sensitive skin: use PHA exfoliants, oily skin: incorporate niacinamide
Age-Specific Considerations: Mature skin: avoid over-drying, teens: focus on prevention
